meanings.def: a long thin piece of potato fried in oil or fat
examples: He was eating a burger and chips.
a bag of chips
All main courses are served with chips or baked potato.
All he'll eat is chips.
I never cook anything grand—we live on chips and baked beans.

meanings.def: a thin round slice of potato that is fried until hard then dried and eaten cold. Chips are sold in bags and are made to taste of many different foods.
examples: a bag of chips

meanings.def: a small flat hard piece of food, often like a triangle in shape, made from maize
the place from which a small piece of wood, glass, etc. has broken from an object
examples: This mug has a chip in it.
She had a slight chip off her front tooth.

meanings.def: a small piece of wood, glass, etc. that has broken or been broken off an object
examples: chips of wood
chocolate chip cookies (= biscuits containing small pieces of chocolate)
The gutted raw fish are smoked slowly over wood chips.

meanings.def: a small flat piece of plastic used to represent a particular amount of money in some types of gambling
examples: a poker chip

meanings.def: an act of hitting or kicking a ball high in the air so that it lands within a short distance
examples: She left herself with a short chip to the green.
He cashed in his chips last summer aged 65.

meanings.def: a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave
to be sensitive about something that happened in the past and become easily offended if it is mentioned because you think that you were treated unfairly
examples: He has a real chip on his shoulder about being adopted.

meanings.def: to be in a situation in which you are certain to be defeated or killed
used to refer to a difficult situation in which you are forced to decide what is important to you
examples: I'm not sure what I'll do when the chips are down.
When the chips are down he always finds the courage to carry on.
He cashed in his chips last summer aged 65.

idioms.idiom: a chip off the old block
idioms.def: a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave

idioms.idiom: have a chip on your shoulder (about something)
idioms.def: to be sensitive about something that happened in the past and become easily offended if it is mentioned because you think that you were treated unfairly
examples: He has a real chip on his shoulder about being adopted.

idioms.def: to be in a situation in which you are certain to be defeated or killed
used to refer to a difficult situation in which you are forced to decide what is important to you
examples: I'm not sure what I'll do when the chips are down.
When the chips are down he always finds the courage to carry on.

meanings.def: to damage something by breaking a small piece off it; to become damaged in this way
examples: a badly chipped saucer
She chipped one of her front teeth.
These plates chip easily.
She fell and chipped her tooth badly.

meanings.def: to cut or break small pieces off something with a tool
examples: Chip away the damaged area.
The fossils had been chipped out of the rock.
It took a long time to chip a hole in the wall.
It needs skill to chip a block of stone into a recognizable shape.
We chipped the paint off the wood.

meanings.def: to hit or kick the ball so that it goes high in the air and then lands within a short distance
to cut potatoes into long thin pieces in order to fry them in deep oil
to put a microchip under the skin of a dog or other animal so that it can be identified if it is lost or stolen
